title: Global Economy Week Ahead
summary: In the week ahead, the U.S. Federal Reserve releases January meeting minutes. The U.S. will also see fresh data on home sales and durable goods..

title: Battle to Capture Last of ISIS Territory Slows
summary: Militants hiding among civilians have slowed an advance. BAGHDAD-Islamic State militants hiding among civilians have slowed an advance by U.S.-backed coalition forces in Syria, said the top American ground commander, a setback in the fight to reclaim the last vestiges of Islamic State's territory.

title: Sound Advice for Choosing a Financial Adviser
summary: When the financial wisdom you pick up in The Wall Street Journal doesn't fit your needs, a financial professional may be your smartest option. It can be difficult to accept that someone could have a better handle on your money than you do. But when advice in the pages of The Wall Street Journal isn't specific enough to your situation, a financial professional may be your smartest option.

title: NYPD Seeks Authority to Disable Drones
summary: Officials cite increasing concern about terrorists weaponizing devices. The New York Police Department wants the authority to take down drones it deems a threat.

title: Democrats Ready to Challenge Trump's Emergency Move
summary: California plans to sue the administration, in concert with other states, over the president's use of emergency powers to fund a border wall. WASHINGTON-Democrats on Sunday signaled they are gearing up to challenge President Trump's use of his emergency powers to fund construction of a wall along the southern U.S. border, an expected move that would likely tie up implementation of one of his core campaign promises.

title: Partisan Rift Threatens Federal Data-Privacy Efforts
summary: Silicon Valley and GOP lawmakers want a national standard that would override state regulations but are facing pushback from Democrats. WASHINGTON-Congress set the stage last year to pass a sweeping consumer data-privacy law in 2019, but prospects for legislation are dimming amid sharpening divides among lawmakers over how far the federal government should go in reining in Big Tech.

title: When Investing Is About the CEO's Goodwill
summary: Santander's decision not to buy back convertible debt should remind investors of hidden risks in CoCo bonds. It is hard to feel sorry for investors whining that a Spanish bank decided not to buy back €1.5 billion of junior convertible debt, as such banks usually do. Buyers, it is easy to argue, should read the terms and conditions next time instead of relying on the issuer to follow market custom.

title: Chicago Police Investigating Whether Smollett Coordinated Alleged Attack
summary: Two potential suspects admit purchasing rope involved in incident, but weren't working alone, people familiar with the matter said. CHICAGO-Chicago police are investigating whether Jussie Smollett, the "Empire" television star who said he was attacked last month by two people yelling racial and gay epithets, coordinated the attack, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: Pence's Calls to Pressure Iran Fall on Deaf Ears in Europe
summary: Officials said the U.S. vice president's remarks could weaken Washington's efforts to tighten coordination over shared concerns. MUNICH-European officials brushed off U.S. Vice President Mike Pence's calls during a diplomatic trip to the continent this week to ratchet up pressure on Iran, saying they will continue defending the 2015 nuclear deal and stay engaged with Iran's government.

title: Lawsuits Surge Over Websites' Access for the Blind
summary: Complaints are new frontier in federal disability litigation, typically detailing roadblocks for 'screen reader' tools that read content aloud. Businesses with websites that can't be navigated by the blind are getting pummeled with lawsuits.

title: Voter Initiatives, Including Medicaid Expansion, Could Get Harder to Pass
summary: Lawmakers in Florida, Missouri weigh fees, mandating more petition signatures and other requirements. Some Republican lawmakers are moving to curtail future state voter initiatives, posing a possible obstacle to supporters of Medicaid expansion, who are already locked in a bitter fight to preserve initiatives passed in the November midterm elections.

title: Worry About Debt? Not So Fast, Some Economists Say
summary: U.S. deficits may not matter so much after all-and it might not hurt to expand them for the right reasons. As the national debt swells, some economists are making a once-heretical argument: The U.S. needn't be so worried about all of its red ink.

title: Phylicia Rashad Is Everybody's Mom
summary: Often cast as the matriarch on stage and screen, the actress's latest fictional mother appears in the NBC drama 'This Is Us'. Phylicia Rashad has two children, but she has acted as a mother to many more in a career defined by maternal roles.

title: A $10 Accessory Proves Smartphones Are Too Big
summary: A PopSocket grip is the best way to make sure you can actually hold your big, hard-to-handle phone. The smartphone surely belongs on the list of truly game-changing innovations, right there with indoor plumbing, penicillin and the thumbs-up. You can have mine when you pry it out of my cold, dead hand.

title: Amazon Fiasco Splits New York's Left
summary: Not every city Democrat is an antibusiness progressive like Bill de Blasio and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.. From 30,000 feet, Amazon's abandonment of its proposed new headquarters in New York City might seem a chance, as Bostonian snobs like to put it, for the light to dawn on Marblehead.

title: Investors Get Burned After Betting on Electric-Car Metals
summary: Markets like stocks and oil have rebounded this year, but cobalt and lithium continue to fall. Investors who piled into electric-car metals can't seem to catch a break.

title: Import Wave Jams California Warehouses
summary: The seaborne trade from Asia has barely slowed since the peak shipping season, tying up distribution networks and storage space. LOS ANGELES-A steady wave of imports into Southern California's ports, driven by a robust U.S. economy and companies trying to get goods moving ahead of potential tariffs, has the region's warehouses and shipping terminals overstuffed and distribution networks jammed.

title: Heather Nauert Withdraws as Trump's Pick for U.S. Ambassador to U.N.
summary: State Department says Ms. Nauert withdrew for family reasons. WASHINGTON-Heather Nauert, who was President Trump's pick to serve as the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, has withdrawn from consideration, the State Department said Saturday night.
